title: Revoked User can still view  the Merge Request  created by him via API

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
### Summary

In Gitlab when a user is demoted to Guest role, the Guest user will not be able to view and edit the Merge requests in a project even if the merge request is created by him. But this check is not implemented in API so the Guest user will be able to the following actions for the Merge request which he don't have a permission.

Allowed Actions in API 

- Able to view the title and Description of the Merge Request via   /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid endpoint
- Get a list of merge request participants via /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/participants
- Get a list of merge request commits via /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/commits 
- Get  information about the merge request including its files and changes via /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/changes
- Get a list of merge request pipelines via /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/pipelines
- Create a TODO for that Merge Request via POST /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/todo
- Get a list of merge request diff versions via /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/versions
- Get Merge Request approvals status via /projects/:id/merge_requests/:merge_request_iid/approvals

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add a user a to a project with developer role.
2. From the Added user account create a Merge Request 
3. From Admin account demote to the user to Guest Role
4. From the Guest user account try to access the Merge request created by that user. (Merge Request tab will not be available for that user)
5. Now Create an access token from the Guest user account and try to access the Merge Request created by the user  by the above mentioned any one of the endpoints  (Notice you will be able to view  the Merge Request)

### Impact

Guest Role users have access to Merge Request data that he's not authorised to view and Edit

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Guest Roles users have access to Merge Request data that he's not authorised to view and Edit via API

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Guest Roles users should be restricted  access to Merge Request  to view and Edit via API

### Output of checks

 This bug happens on GitLab.com

## Impact

Guest Role users have access to Merge Request data that he's not authorised to view and Edit

activities.message:
Hi @muthu199503,

Thank you for submitting this report! We will investigate the issue as soon as
possible, and should get back within a week.

Please do not submit your report or ask about its status through additional
channels, as this unnecessarily binds resources in the security team.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi Team,
I forgot to mention one point. This issue is only applicable for private projects. For public projects the Merge requests are publicly visible

Hi @muthu_prakash,
Thanks for the report. 
As per your reproduction steps, I tried accessing the mentioned API endpoints with a guest user's personal access token, however, only the error message `"message":"403 Forbidden"` was observed from application responses. 
Would you be able to provide raw HTTP requests and responses or a screen recording that displays the successful attempts?

Best regards,
Tommy
GitLab Security Team

Hi @tommzxcv,

Thanks for looking into the report. You are correct, as per my steps when accessing the merge request, it shows `message":"403 Forbidden` only. It seems the Guest user can access the merge request assigned to him not created by him when his access is revoked.  Apologies on my side.
My internet is slow. I am trying to attach a video POC. but it will take some time

Video POC: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IZXDJjYeLHK7OncEX-n3UvgxrAF-flXD/view?usp=sharing

Hackerone upload is very slow for my internet connection.  I uploaded the POC in Google Drive.

Hi @muthu_prakash,
Thanks for providing the screen recording. However, I am still not able to reproduce it and the following steps were performed. 
- create a merge request from owner -> assign it to userB (Developer role) 
- userB is then downgraded to Guest role
- create a personal access token from userB account
- access the API endpoint `/api/v4/projects/[project_id]/merge_requests/[MR_id]` with newly created token. `403 Forbidden` is observed. 

Also, even if the claim that you are making in this report is correct, I am wondering how could this lead to any security risk to our users given that owner is the one how creates the merge request for some reasons and assigns it to a user, which we can perhaps assume that this is the true intention from the owner. userB can then be unassigned by the owner at any time otherwise. 
Therefore, I would really appreciate it if you could provide the clear written steps involved from the very beginning of starting a project and creating a branch until the exposure to a Guest user along with a realistic attack scenario that could impact confidentiality, integrity and availability of our users. Thank you! 

Best regards,
Tommy
GitLab Security Team

Hi @tommzxcv,

Thanks for looking into the report. As per your steps it should work. I double checked again on my side on both gitlab.com and local Gitlab instance. Perhaps could you give me access to your testing project so that I can check or I can give access to my testing project to you to simulate the scenario. 

 >Also, even if the claim that you are making in this report is correct, I am wondering how could this lead to any security risk to our users given that owner is the one how creates the merge request for some reasons and assigns it to a user, which we can perhaps assume that this is the true intention from the owner. userB can then be unassigned by the owner at any time otherwise.


The main reason of demoting a user to Guest role is to restrict data. But The API clearly exposes data that the user is not intended to see. Merge requests sure contain confidential data and I can see that this check is implemented properly on web app but not in the API.


These are the exact steps  followed on my side on gitlab.com

- Created a new Project with private access
- Created a new file in master branch (Made some changes )
- Invited a user with a developer role.
- From the developer role account created a new branch named test, made some changes.
- After that from project admin account I created a Merge request with source branch as test and target branch as master. 
- Assigned that merge request to the developer role access user.
- After creating the merge request, from project admin account demoted the developer role user to Guest role
- From demoted user account  I created a personal access token with all the available scopes selected
- From API client (Postman) I sent a request to merge_request endpoint you  mentioned. (In that case the merge_request id will be 1 since only one merge request is created)
- I was able to access the merge request details assigned to demoted user. If i try to access the merge requests which are not assigned to that demoted account. It shows `403 Forbidden`



Let me know if you need any further details

Hello @muthu_prakash,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/243491.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

Given the severity of the report, we are paying an initial $500 on triage. Congratulations!

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Tommy
GitLab Security Team

Hi @tommzxcv,
Thanks for the update and bounty

ETA for fix:

Hi @muthu_prakash,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2020-12-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @muthu_prakash,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been reviewed and we are awarding a bounty prior the release of a patch. Congratulations!

We will continue to keep you updated via HackerOne as a fix is scheduled.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @muthu_prakash,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-01-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @muthu_prakash,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-02-28.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @muthu_prakash,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been patched in GitLab version 13.8.4. Congratulations!

Please let us know if you find that our patch does not mitigate your finding. Your report will be published in 30 days in GitLab's issue tracker.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
Costel
GitLab Security Team

Hey @muthu_prakash, 

We can disclose it and the internal Gitlab issue in 30 day after the fix was released.

Regards,
Costel
